JUDGES: Anatoly Kovler;Christos Rozakis;Elisabeth Steiner;George Nicolaou;Khanlar Hajiyev;Peer Lorenzen
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant was born in DATE and lives in PERSON .

CARDINAL . NORP In DATE the police , at the request of the ORG Attorney , commenced an inquiry into allegations that during DATE , at the beginning of the Homeland War in GPE , a large number of civilians were tortured and killed or detained in GPE , GPE by members of the so - called “ GPE ” ( Milicija “ Autonomne Oblasti Krajina ” ) , where they were allegedly tortured and some of them killed . A large number of survivors and other individuals who witnessed these events were interviewed by the police . A voluminous case file was produced and the inquiry resulted in the supposed perpetrators being identified , among whom was the applicant .

CARDINAL . The applicant was arrested on DATE on suspicion that he had committed war crimes against the civilian population and prisoners of war . On DATE the investigation judge of ORG ( istražni sudac ORG ) heard evidence from the applicant in the presence of a defence counsel . The applicant denied the charges . On DATE the investigation judge heard evidence from CARDINAL other suspects .

CARDINAL . On DATE an investigation was opened in respect of the applicant and CARDINAL other suspects in ORG in connection with suspected war crimes against the civilian population and prisoners of war in DATE in GPE , GPE .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the police interviewed CARDINAL newly discovered potential witnesses .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation judge requested a report from ORG ( NORP za socijalnu skrb PERSON ) on the PERSON personal circumstances . On DATE the investigation judge scheduled a hearing , with an identification parade , for DATE , and ordered ORG to ensure the presence of CARDINAL other individuals of an appropriate age and physical appearance at the identification parade .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE the investigation judge heard evidence from CARDINAL witnesses and held an identification parade . CARDINAL of the witnesses were asked to identify the applicant and both of them recognised the applicant as a person named PERSON who they alleged had ill - treated prisoners in PERSON in DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG asked for evidence from CARDINAL witnesses to be heard by the investigation judge .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG submitted their report to ORG on the applicant ’s personal circumstances . The report stated that the applicant and his family , who had left GPE during the Homeland War , had returned to GPE in DATE and since then had lived in their own house in PERSON . Before his arrest the applicant had been employed as a driver in GPE , GPE . On DATE ORG informed ORG that the applicant had been fined twice for minor offences related to road safety and customs regulations . He had no criminal record .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation judge heard evidence from CARDINAL and CARDINAL witnesses respectively . A voluminous case file was compiled containing evidence from witnesses and a large amount of documentary evidence .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant and another defendant were indicted before ORG for war crimes against prisoners of war , an offence under LAW of LAW . The applicant was accused of inflicting exceptionally brutal treatment on prisoners of war on several occasions , consisting of beatings with wooden rods and chains , kicking , administering electric shocks , death threats and forcing schoolchildren to urinate on the prisoners .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant lodged an objection to the indictment ( prigovor protiv optužnice ) . His co - defendant also lodged an objection .
CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG asked ORG to transfer jurisdiction to another court . This was refused on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the objections to the indictment were dismissed by ORG and the indictment became final .

CARDINAL . On DATE the President of ORG again asked ORG to transfer jurisdiction to another court . On DATE ORG transferred jurisdiction to ORG ( Županijski sud u ORG ) and the proceedings continued before that court .
CARDINAL . A hearing scheduled for DATE was adjourned owing to the absence of the parties .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant appointed new counsel , who asked ORG to adjourn the trial in order to allow him sufficient time to consult the case file and prepare the applicant ’s defence . For that reason on DATE ORG adjourned the hearings already scheduled for CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and DATE . The hearings were scheduled for CARDINAL , DATE , DATE and DATE .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE ORG dismissed a number of procedural objections put forward by the defence and heard evidence from CARDINAL witness . A hearing scheduled for DATE was adjourned because the defence counsel of both defendants refused to continue to represent them . On DATE ORG appointed legal - aid counsel for the applicant . On DATE the appointed counsel asked to be relieved of his duties . On DATE ORG accepted this request and on DATE it appointed new legal - aid counsel for the applicant . On DATE that lawyer also sought to be relieved of her duties . On DATE ORG refused this request . On DATE counsel again sought to be relieved of her duties , on different grounds from those given in her previous request . This request was accepted on DATE and on DATE new legal - aid defence counsel was appointed .

CARDINAL . A hearing scheduled for CARDINAL DATE was adjourned because the applicant ’s counsel did not appear . A hearing scheduled for DATE was adjourned because the case file had been forwarded to ORG upon the applicant ’s appeal against a decision extending his detention ( see below , § DATE ) .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE ORG heard evidence from CARDINAL witnesses , on DATE CARDINAL witnesses and on DATE also CARDINAL witnesses . On DATE ORG commissioned an expert report from a medical expert . On DATE the expert submitted her report .
CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE ORG heard evidence from the medical expert and at a hearing held on DATE it heard evidence from CARDINAL witnesses .
CARDINAL . A hearing scheduled for DATE was adjourned on account of the applicant ’s inability to attend owing to his post - surgery state of health ( see below , § § DATE ) .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE the ORG heard the applicant ’s evidence as to his health and decided to commission a report by a medical expert concerning the applicant ’s health . The report was submitted on DATE . The expert stated that the applicant ’s health was not incompatible with his ability to attend and follow the criminal trial against him ( see below , § CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE the records of the identification parade ( see above , § CARDINAL ) were read and CARDINAL witnesses gave evidence .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE ORG decided on a number of procedural objections put forward by the defence . At a hearing on DATE CARDINAL witnesses and both defendants gave evidence and the parties gave their closing arguments .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG found the applicant guilty of war crimes against prisoners of war and sentenced him to four years’ imprisonment . At the same time it lifted the applicant ’s detention .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE respectively the applicant and the other defendant lodged their appeals . The appeal proceedings are currently pending before ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation judge of ORG remanded the applicant in custody for TIME . On DATE the investigation judge heard evidence from the applicant in the presence of a defence counsel . The applicant denied the charges against him . On DATE the investigation judge heard evidence from CARDINAL other suspects .

CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation judge remanded the applicant in custody for DATE on the grounds that there was a danger of absconding and that the offences allegedly committed by the applicant were serious ones . The relevant part of the decision reads :
“ This court finds that the grounds for detention under LAW and CARDINAL ) of LAW apply ...

The case file shows that the first , second and third suspects lived in GPE for a long time and therefore the circumstances indicated a danger of absconding because they might leave the territory of GPE and thus impede the conduct of these criminal proceedings .

Also , what is at issue is a crime against humanity and international law – a war crime against prisoners of war , liable to DATE imprisonment , which was committed under particularly grave circumstances shown by a reasonable suspicion that the suspects brutally tortured the prisoners , and the injuries thus inflicted caused grave bodily impairments to the majority of the victims , resulting in their permanent grave disability . ”
This decision was upheld by a CARDINAL - judge panel of ORG on DATE which endorsed the reasoning of the investigation judge .
CARDINAL . On DATE the investigation judge extended the applicant ’s detention for a further DATE on the same grounds as before . The applicant did not lodge an appeal .

CARDINAL . On DATE a CARDINAL - judge panel of ORG extended the applicant ’s detention on the same grounds ( danger of absconding and gravity of offences ) . This decision was upheld by ORG on DATE . The relevant part of the decision reads :

“ This court finds that the fact that the defendants lived abroad for a long time and are charged with a grave criminal offence liable to a lengthy prison term show that if released , they might abscond . Thus , the extension of their detention on the ground under LAW ) of LAW is justified .

ORG ... accepts the first - instance court ’s findings that the conduct of the defendants amounted to an offence committed under particularly grave circumstances , which necessitate their further detention on the ground under LAW CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW . The defendants are charged with particularly brutal conduct consisting of beatings with wooden sticks , rods and chains , administering electric shocks , throwing cold water over and psychologically torturing war prisoners GPE , GPE and ORG on many occasions in cells , halls and the courtyard of the building where they were detained , which caused grave bodily injuries to the victims . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the applicant ’s detention on the same grounds .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG quashed the decision of DATE on formal grounds , namely the absence of the applicant ’s defence counsel from a panel meeting concerning his detention .
CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE the ORG extended the applicant ’s detention on the same grounds . The applicant did not lodge an appeal .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE ORG extended the applicant ’s detention on the same grounds . The applicant did not lodge appeals .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the applicant ’s detention solely on account of the gravity of the offences . The relevant part of the decision reads :

“ This panel finds that the grounds for detention under LAW CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW in respect of the first defendant PERSON still apply on account of the manner in which he had allegedly committed the criminal offences held against him . The factual basis of the criminal offence shows exceptional cruelty and brutality which , in the opinion of this panel , represent an offence committed under exceptionally grave circumstances and that therefore detention is necessary under LAW CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW .

The record of the hearing held on DATE shows that the first defendant PERSON is a citizen of GPE , that he was employed as a driver before his arrest , that he owns CARDINAL a house in PERSON , and that he is married and the father of CARDINAL children . These circumstances show that he has a connection with GPE and that , despite these criminal proceedings and a risk of imprisonment , the grounds for detention under LAW ) of LAW have not been fulfilled , namely that there are no circumstances indicating a danger of absconding . ”
On DATE ORG upheld this decision , endorsing ORG reasons . The applicant lodged a constitutional complaint .
CARDINAL . NORP On DATE the applicant asked for his detention to be lifted .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG dismissed the applicant ’s request and extended the applicant ’s detention on account of the gravity of the charges . On DATE ORG upheld this decision , endorsing ORG reasoning .

CARDINAL . At the hearing held on DATE the applicant ’s counsel asked for the detention to be lifted on the ground that he needed medical assistance outside prison , including surgery on his spine . ORG dismissed the request , finding that it was premature , since no surgery had yet been performed on the applicant . On DATE the applicant was admitted to ORG ( GPE lišene slobode , “ the ZPH ” ) . On DATE he was transferred to a civil hospital , where surgery on his spine was carried out on DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again asked for his detention to be lifted on health grounds . This was refused by ORG on DATE and the applicant ’s detention was extended for a further DATE . The relevant part of that decision reads as follows :

“ This court finds that the ground for ordering the applicant ’s detention under LAW paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW still exists because of ... a suspicion that in the period between DATE and DATE the first defendant , PERSON , as a member of the intervention brigade of ORG so - called GPE , on several occasions brutally ill - treated prisoners of war in the cells , corridor and courtyard of the ORG building by beating them with wooden sticks , rods and chains , kicking them and administering electric shocks until they lost consciousness .

These circumstances indicate utterly cruel and inhuman treatment of the prisoners of war , which significantly exceeded the basic features of the crime in question ... which represent an offence committed under particularly grave circumstances , which clearly warrant that the defendant remain in custody on the grounds under LAW paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW . ”
CARDINAL . As to the applicant ’s request that his detention be lifted , ORG held :

“ This court finds the first defendant ’s request for his detention to be lifted unfounded . The purpose of placing the first defendant PERSON in FAC is precisely to be able to administer adequate medical care appropriate to his needs and state of health . [ The ORG ] is able to provide continuous monitoring and urgent medical interventions . There it is possible to administer the medical assistance the defendant needs , identical to that which he would receive in any other situation , irrespective of whether or not he is in detention . ”
This decision was upheld by ORG on DATE . The relevant part of the decision reads :
“ ... the finding of the first - instance court that the ground for further detention of the defendant PERSON under CARDINAL paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW still applied is correct .

The indictment shows a relevant degree of reasonable suspicion that the defendant PERSON committed the criminal offence under LAW , by which a general statutory condition under LAW paragraph CARDINAL of LAW for extending detention has been fulfilled .

The factual background of the indictment shows that the defendant PERSON , in his capacity as a member of the intervention squad of the so - called LOC A[utonomous ] R[egion ] ORG , in the period from DATE to DATE , together with other members of that militia , on many occasions , in cells , hall and courtyard of the building [ where they were detained ] kicked prisoners and beat them with wooden sticks , rods and chains on the head and body and administered electric shocks until they lost consciousness , all of which resulted in numerous and grave injuries .

The above - described manner in which the offences were committed shows an exceptionally high degree of brutality , ruthlessness , unscrupulousness and cruelty , which surpasses by far the usual manner of committing such crimes and represents an offence committed under particularly grave circumstances which necessitates the defendants’ remaining in custody under LAW paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW , as correctly found and explained by the first - instance court in the decision referred to .

The defendant ’s arguments that there was no proof that he had committed the criminal offences at issue are not decisive for deciding on his further detention , because for such a decision the relevant degree of reasonable suspicion suffices , and that suspicion is shown in the indictment .
In considering [ the reasons for ] detention , this panel does not assess evidence and its probative value – that assessment is made by the trial court at the end of the trial .

Contrary to the allegations of the appeal , the extension of his detention on the grounds under LAW paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW contravenes neither LAW nor LAW . Unlike the aim of the grounds for detention under LAW paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL,CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) of LAW , the aim of the ground for detention under LAW paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW is not to remove threats to the efficient and unobstructed conduct of the criminal proceedings but is preventive , intended to prevent the release of individuals who have committed criminal offences such that their release would diminish the reputation of and trust in the justice system by the public . LAW gives only examples of the grounds for detention ( exempli gratia ) and these grounds are not exclusive ( numerus clausus ) . Therefore , LAW paragraph CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) does not contravene the said provision of the LAW . Other security measures under LAW , in view of their essence and character , could not fulfil the same purpose as detention .
The applicant ’s needs as regards medical care may be satisfied with medical treatment in prison , in view of the nature of his illness , and exceptionally by out - patient treatment . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant again asked for his detention to be lifted on health grounds .

CARDINAL . On CARDINAL DATE ORG declared the applicant ’s constitutional complaint against ORG decision of DATE inadmissible on the grounds that meanwhile a fresh decision extending the applicant ’s detention had been adopted by ORG on DATE and that therefore the original decision was no longer in effect .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant ’s request of CARDINAL DATE was dismissed by ORG on the grounds that the applicant ’s health did not require treatment outside prison . The relevant part of the decision reads :

“ As regards the health of the first defendant PERSON ... this panel finds that for now the treatment it requires is not incompatible with his detention . The medical documentation of CARDINAL DATE shows that a haematoma which developed ... in the brain , is slowly diminishing . The neurosurgeons did not recommend surgery but only further supervision and rest . The next examination ... is scheduled for DATE . His health is expected to become stable . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG extended the applicant ’s detention on the grounds of the gravity of the charges .

DATE . On DATE , after finding the applicant guilty of war crimes against prisoners of war , ORG lifted his detention . The applicant was released DATE . A security measure of withdrawal of his passport and prohibition on leaving his place of residence was applied . The relevant part of the decision lifting the applicant ’s detention reads :

“ ... there is no ground for further detention of the defendant because the same purpose may be achieved by the use of a preventive measure of prohibition on leaving his place of residence and obligation to report periodically to ORG as well as temporary seizure of his passport . ”
CARDINAL . The applicant ’s medical record shows that before his arrest he was suffering from discopathy of the lumbar spinal area .

CARDINAL . He was seen by the prison doctor on DATE for severe pain in the lumbar area of the spine and the left leg . He was diagnosed with lumboischialgia ( chronic neck pain ) , and prescribed painkillers and rest . At his next examination on CARDINAL DATE the doctor noted that the pain was decreasing and the same therapy was prescribed . On further examinations by the prison doctor on DATE , CARDINAL , DATE , DATE , DATE and DATE it was noted that the applicant was still suffering pain and he was prescribed various painkillers .

CARDINAL . On DATE the doctor recommended that the applicant be seen by an orthopedic specialist . On DATE the applicant stated that he wanted to see a specialist at his own expense at a hospital of his choice . On DATE a trial judge in the applicant ’s case before ORG allowed the request and a visit to a clinic was scheduled for DATE .
CARDINAL . At DATE the applicant was sent for an ORG examination of his spine .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant asked permission to undergo a computer tomography of his spine in a private clinic . The request was allowed on DATE by the trial judge and the visit to the clinic was scheduled for DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the trial judge allowed the applicant a specialist examination at the expense of ORG .

CARDINAL . On DATE the trial judge allowed the applicant ’s treatment in FAC ( ZPH ) at the expense of ORG . The applicant stayed in the ORG from DATE to DATE . He was diagnosed with disc protrusion and surgery on his spine was scheduled for DATE .

CARDINAL . On DATE the Rijeka Prison doctor submitted a report on the applicant ’s health to ORG . She stated that he was suffering from disc protrusion and that surgery was scheduled for DATE at a civilian hospital - ORG in GPE ( ORG bolnički centar PERSON ) . She further noted that he had been taking painkillers for a long time and recommended that he rest TIME because he was not able to sit for a long period in the same position .
CARDINAL . At a hearing held in ORG on DATE an independent medical expert recommended that a TIME break be taken TIME during the hearing on account of the applicant ’s health problems .
CARDINAL . On DATE the trial judge allowed the applicant ’s hospitalisation in ORG in GPE for him to undergo surgery on his spine on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant was admitted to the ZPH . On DATE he was transferred to ORG where he underwent surgery on his spine on DATE . On DATE he was returned to the ZPH .

CARDINAL . After the surgery the applicant developed a haematoma in the cerebellum . He underwent physiotherapy . A number of laboratory tests were carried out as well as several brain nuclear magnetic resonances , computer tomography of his spine and head , X - ray of his mouth cavity and electrocardiography . He was seen by an oral surgeon , neurologist , physiologist , ophthalmologist and a psychologist . A neurosurgeon examined him on DATE and CARDINAL DATE and DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE he was returned to PERSON .

CARDINAL . At a hearing held on DATE in ORG , the trial judge asked for an opinion from a medical expert . On DATE an independent medical expert , who saw the applicant on DATE , submitted his opinion , stating that the applicant ’s health was not incompatible with his ability to attend and follow the criminal trial against him . He further recommended a brain examination at DATE or beginning of DATE , an examination by a neurosurgeon and physiotherapy .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of LAW ( Osnovni krivični zakon , Official Gazette no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL ) reads as follows :

Whoever , in violation of the rules of international law , orders the killing , torture or inhuman treatment of prisoners of war , including biological , medical or other scientific experiments , the removal of tissue or organs for transplantation , or the causing of great suffering or injury to their physical integrity or health ; or compels a prisoner of war to serve in the forces of a hostile power , or deprives a prisoner of war of the right to a fair trial ; or commits any of the foregoing acts , shall be sentenced to not less than DATE imprisonment or up to DATE imprisonment .
CARDINAL . The relevant part of LAW ( Zakon o kaznenom postupku , ORG nos . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , DATE , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL , CARDINAL and DATE ) provides as follows :

“ ( CARDINAL ) Where the conditions for ordering detention under LAW have been fulfilled , and where the same purpose may be achieved by other preventive measures under LAW , the court shall order that CARDINAL or more preventive measures are to be applied ...
( CARDINAL ) Preventive measures are :
CARDINAL ) prohibition on leaving one ’s place of residence ;
CARDINAL ) prohibition on being in a certain place or area ;
CARDINAL ) obligation on the defendant to report periodically to a certain person or a ORG body ;
CARDINAL ) prohibition on access to a certain person or on establishing or maintaining contact with a certain person ;
CARDINAL ) prohibition on undertaking a certain business activity ;
CARDINAL ) temporary seizure of a passport or other document necessary for crossing the State border ;
CARDINAL ) temporary seizure of a driving licence .
“ ( CARDINAL ) Detention may be imposed only if the same purpose can not be achieved by another [ preventive ] measure .
( CARDINAL ) Detention shall be lifted and the detainee released as soon as the grounds for detention cease to exist .

( CARDINAL ) When deciding on detention , in particular its duration , a court shall take into consideration the proportionality between the gravity of the offence , the sentence which ... may be expected to be imposed , and the need to order and determine the duration of detention .

( CARDINAL ) ORG authorities conducting criminal proceedings shall proceed with particular urgency when the defendant is in detention and shall review ex officio whether the grounds and legal conditions for detention have ceased to exist , in which case detention shall immediately be lifted . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) Where a reasonable suspicion exists that a person has committed an offence , that person may be placed in detention :
CARDINAL . where there are circumstances which show that there is a risk hat [ the defendant ] will abscond [ is in hiding or his or her identity can not be established etc . ) ;

CARDINAL . where the charges relate to murder , robbery , rape , terrorism , kidnapping , abuse of narcotic drugs , extortion or any other offence carrying a sentence of CARDINAL years’ imprisonment , or where detention is justified by the modus operandi or other especially grave circumstances of the offence . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of ORG o izvršavanju kazne zatvora , ORG nos . ORG ) read as follows :
“ ( CARDINAL ) Inmates shall have the right to complain about an act or decision of a prison employee .

( CARDINAL ) Complaints shall be lodged orally or in writing with a prison governor , a judge responsible for the execution of sentences or ORG . Written complaints addressed to a judge responsible for the execution of sentences or ORG shall be submitted in an envelope which the prison authorities may not open ... ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) Inmates shall be provided with medical treatment and proper care of their physical and mental health ... ”
( CARDINAL ) A doctor shall examine a sick or injured inmate ... and undertake all measures necessary to prevent or cure the illness and to prevent deterioration of the inmate ’s health . ”
“ ( CARDINAL ) An inmate has the right to seek a specialist examination if such an examination has not been ordered by a prison doctor .
( CARDINAL ) Temporary release may be allowed on the following grounds :
CARDINAL ) to an inmate suffering from a serious acute illness or whose chronic illness worsens and where his or her medical treatment is not possible in prison .
